last philosopher of the talk this is a guy called Paul Grace he was British uh
philosopher of language um and the thing that he came up with that's interesting to us today
is the idea of the Cooperative principle and what he meant by this is the idea
that when you're communicating cooperatively with somebody there are some rules that he noticed tend to arise
in those kinds of communications and what he meant by cooperatively is you're not telling a joke you're not lying
you're not trying to manipulate somebody you are genuinely working together to do in the best faith possible the process
of getting an idea from one person's head to another and bring your ideas into alignment and what he noticed was that
there are four sort of categories of rules four things that he noticed came
up again and again and again in these kinds of communications as he observed them and they are called grais maxims so
the first first one is the maximum of quantity when you're communicating cooperatively you should include all the
information that's necessary don't leave things out but also don't give too much don't info dump too much don't include
stuff that's not actually relevant the second one is the maxim of Truth don't say don't don't don't lie
right if you're communicating cooperatively don't say things that you don't believe to be true reasonably
believe to be true like it's okay not to be 100% sure of something because as we've talked about you know you can
never be 100% sure what's in someone else's head so does that mean you just don't speculate about what somebody else

the maximum of truth don't lie you've got the maximum of relevance and this ties into the maximum of

the maximum of clarity which is don't use big furus words say what you mean as
clearly as possible in a way that is designed to be understandable by the
